metadata.titleEn: Dataset of global future urban expansion (2020-2070) V1.0
metadata.description: This dataset derives from the article: He, C., Liu, Z., Wu, J., Pan, X., Fang, Z., Li, J., Bryan, B.A. (2021). Future global urban water scarcity and potential solutions. Nature Communications, 12, 4667. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-25026-3. This dataset includes global urban land information under different shared socioeconomic pathways from 2020 to 2070. The production process of this dataset mainly includes: (1) establishing a linear regression model based on the urban land data (downloaded from https://doi.pangaea.de/10.1594/PANGAEA.892684) and urban population data from 1992 to 2016 to calculate the future urban land demand; (2) using the LUSD-urban model to simulate the spatial distribution of urban land. The dataset can support the assessment of effects of future global urban expansion.
metadata.instructions:
File name: the file is stored in the form of grid data. The file name is "ssp scenario _yyyy", where "ssp scenario" represents the shared socio-economic pathway and "yyyy" represents the year, for example, ssp1_ 2050. tif represents the grid file to describe the global urban land information in 2050 under SSP1.
Data reading mode: users can use geographic information systems and remote sensing related software such as ESRI ArcGIS software, ERDAS software and ENVI software to read data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection method that uses linear regression models to calculate future urban built-up area requirements?
Feature Specification.Answer: linear regression models, urban built-up area data from 1992-2016, urban population data, historical trends analysis, future extrapolation

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about future urban expansion patterns by analyzing the relationship between past urban built-up area data and urban population data using linear regression models?
Interpretation.Answer: The relationship between past urban built-up area data and urban population data can help in developing linear regression models that predict the demand for future urban built-up areas. This approach allows researchers to understand how urban areas might expand based on historical trends and population growth, providing a basis for understanding future urban expansion patterns under different socio-economic scenarios.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using linear regression models to predict future urban built-up area demands based on historical urban data and population trends?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using linear regression models to predict future urban built-up area demands can provide a quantitative estimate of future urban expansion needs. However, the accuracy of these predictions depends on the quality and representativeness of historical data and population trends. This approach may result in oversimplification if it fails to account for non-linear dynamics, unexpected changes in urban planning policies, or socio-economic disruptions. It may also influence planning and resource allocation strategies, potentially affecting urban sustainability and resilience.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate goal of collecting data on urban built-up areas under different shared socio-economic pathways from 2020 to 2070?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The ultimate goal of collecting data on urban built-up areas under different shared socio-economic pathways from 2020 to 2070 is to provide data support for assessing the impacts of future global urban expansion processes. This includes understanding the potential challenges and solutions for urban water scarcity as part of broader urban planning and sustainability efforts.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be employed to model future urban built-up area spatial patterns in the context of global urbanization scenarios?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To model future urban built-up area spatial patterns, one can use the LUSD-urban model. This involves using global urban built-up area data from 1992-2016 and urban population data to establish a linear regression model, which calculates the future demand for urban built-up areas. The LUSD-urban model then simulates the spatial patterns of these areas under different shared socioeconomic pathways for the years 2020-2070.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the simulation of future urban built-up area spatial patterns using socio-economic pathways over a 50-year period?
Enablement.Answer: The use of LUSD-urban model to simulate future urban built-up area spatial patterns under different shared socio-economic pathways from 2020-2070 enables this analysis.
